page.title: 08ECOLOGY WEST LEOMINSTER
page.content: The area is gently undulating, crossed by two rivers and a brook, flowing from north-west to south-east. The land on either side of these rivers is subject to flooding. The rivers are well-stocked with fish, including trout, perch and eels. Bulrushes and kingcups are to be found on the banks. There are well-established hedgerows, providing a natural habitat for local wildlife. Rabbits, moles, grey squirrels, hedgehogs and foxes are all very common to the area. Badger setts are also to be found. Many wild flowers such as cowslips, primroses and bluebells are now re-establishing themselves since spraying of hedgerows has virtually ceased. The map shows several foot- paths, but some are now ploughed up or have crops sown over them.
